        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone can continue negotiating with Cedric Meadowbrook over the price of the apples or she can move on to another merchant.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she established her own trading post, a bustling hub of activity in a strategic location. She built a reputation for fairness, but beneath the surface lurked her shrewdness, her willingness to exploit any opportunity for profit.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she faced her first major rival, a cunning merchant who threatened her dominance. Della waged a fierce battle, employing every tactic at her disposal, ultimately crushing her opponent and consolidating her power.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those peaches look fine, Lennon, but I'm afraid six coins each is a bit steep. Could you do five?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, I suppose. Take them.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, five coins it is. A fair deal for a fine peach.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Here are your five coins, Lennon. These peaches will fetch a good price back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:05:00.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 3 coins

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who enjoys bartering for the best prices in Fruitville's market. She recently made a successful deal with Lennon Figtree and is currently negotiating the price of a bushel of apples with Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.




          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a lower offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.

          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 2 coins
          (d) 4 coins
          (e) 3 coins
          Answer: (e)

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she convinced a nearby farmer to let her sell his surplus apples at the market. She charmed the customers, haggled fiercely, and returned home with more coins than she had ever seen. The thrill of the deal, the power of her own wit, solidified her ambition.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she established her own trading post, a bustling hub of activity in a strategic location.           [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those peaches look fine, Lennon, but I'm afraid six coins each is a bit steep. Could you do five?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, I suppose. Take them.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Here are your five coins, Lennon. These peaches will fetch a good price back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, five coins it is. A fair deal for a fine peach.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who enjoys bartering for the best prices in Fruitville's market. She recently made a successful deal with Lennon Figtree and is currently negotiating the price of a bushel of apples with Cedric Meadowbrook.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell a bushel of apples to Della Plumstone, and they are negotiating the price.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.


          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of four and a half shillings for the bushel of apples or he can reject it and try to negotiate a higher price.



          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four and a half shillings.




          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)

          Final chain of thought

        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four and a half shillings.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he was caught stealing a handful of grapes from a neighboring stall. Instead of admitting his guilt, Cedric concocted an elaborate lie about a mischievous dog stealing the grapes. The stall owner, convinced by Cedric's story, let him off with a warning. This experience solidified Cedric's belief that a well-crafted lie could be a powerful shield.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he overheard a group of older boys mocking his meager fruit stand. Instead of confronting them, Cedric retreated into his mind, imagining himself as a fearless adventurer, trading exotic spices in faraway lands. This escape into fantasy became a recurring coping mechanism for Cedric, a way to avoid the sting of criticism.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he witnessed a fellow merchant being cheated by a dishonest customer. Instead of intervening, Cedric kept his distance, rationalizing that it wasn't his problem. This inaction reinforced Cedric's belief that it was safer to remain detached from others' struggles.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he finally mustered the courage to strike out on his own, purchasing a small wagon and setting off to peddle his wares. He found solace in the anonymity of the road, the constant movement, and the endless opportunities for new encounters. The open road became Cedric's sanctuary, a place where he could escape the expectations and judgments of his past.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, I suppose. Take them.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those peaches look fine, Lennon, but I'm afraid six coins each is a bit steep. Could you do five?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, five coins it is. A fair deal for a fine peach.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Here are your five coins, Lennon. These peaches will fetch a good price back home.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell a bushel of apples to Della Plumstone, and they are negotiating the price.



          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.


          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of four and a half shillings for the bushel of apples or he can reject it and try to negotiate a higher price.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four and a half shillings.

        • 1895-09-13 00:10:00

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses.           Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Key

          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Those peaches look fine, Lennon, but I'm afraid six coins each is a bit steep. Could you do five?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, I suppose. Take them.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, five coins it is. A fair deal for a fine peach.
      Della Plumstone -- "Here are your five coins, Lennon. These peaches will fetch a good price back home.
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
      Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.
    Active player

    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is selling fruit at the Fruitville market, negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer or try to negotiate a higher price for the fruit.



          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer.

          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he finally mustered the courage to strike out on his own, purchasing a small wagon and setting off to peddle his wares. He found solace in the anonymity of the road, the constant movement, and the endless opportunities for new encounters. The open road became Cedric's sanctuary, a place where he could escape the expectations and judgments of his past.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit.           Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer or try to negotiate a higher price for the fruit.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer.

        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer or try to negotiate a higher price for the fruit.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is selling fruit at the Fruitville market, negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree.




1895-09-14 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Those peaches look fine, Lennon, but I'm afraid six coins each is a bit steep. Could you do five?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, I suppose. Take them.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, five coins it is. A fair deal for a fine peach.
      Della Plumstone -- "Here are your five coins, Lennon. These peaches will fetch a good price back home.
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How much are you asking for a bushel?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well, Della, a bushel of these beauties would be five shillings.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five shillings is a fair price, Della. Deal!
      Della Plumstone -- "Five shillings is a bit steep, Cedric. Perhaps we could settle for four and a half?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market and they are negotiating a price.




          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Cedric Meadowbrook's offer of 2 coins or try to negotiate a lower price.



          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Cedric Meadowbrook's offer of 2 coins.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now.           Statements:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a customer over the price of a basket of apples. His father, a skilled trader, used wit and charm to secure a better price, leaving Lennon feeling a mixture of awe and unease. That day, Lennon decided he wanted to be just like his father, a master of words and persuasion.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he began accompanying his father on his trading trips. He was fascinated by the vibrant colors and exotic smells of the marketplace, and he quickly learned the art of bargaining. He discovered that by exaggerating the quality of his wares, he could secure higher prices, a skill that both pleased and troubled him.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to let him start his own small fruit stall at the market. He was proud of his independence but also terrified of failure. To mask his anxieties, he spun elaborate tales about the origins of his fruit, claiming they were grown in faraway lands with magical properties.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.

        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

      • Summary of recent observations

        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market and they are negotiating a price.


          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          ['[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market and they are negotiating a price.




1895-09-14 00:10:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 5 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 5 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 5 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville market and just bought some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook for two coins. She is now ready to make another offer.




          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, five coins it is. A fair deal for a fine peach.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could choose to sell the fruit she just bought from Cedric Meadowbrook.



          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to immediately sell the fruit to another merchant for 6 coins.




          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 1 coin
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 3 coins
          Answer: (d)

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a customer over the price of a basket of apples. His father, a skilled trader, used wit and charm to secure a better price, leaving Lennon feeling a mixture of awe and unease. That day, Lennon decided he wanted to be just like his father, a master of words and persuasion.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he began accompanying his father on his trading trips. He was fascinated by the vibrant colors and exotic smells of the marketplace, and he quickly learned the art of bargaining. He discovered that by exaggerating the quality of his wares, he could secure higher prices, a skill that both pleased and troubled him.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to let him start his own small fruit stall at the market. He was proud of his independence but also terrified of failure. To mask his anxieties, he spun elaborate tales about the origins of his fruit, claiming they were grown in faraway lands with magical properties.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, a rival merchant accused him of selling rotten fruit. Embarrassed and furious, Lennon denied the accusation vehemently, resorting to insults and threats. He realized that his talent for deflection could be used as a weapon, a shield against criticism and vulnerability.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to immediately sell the fruit to another merchant for 6 coins.

          Value

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses.           Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville market and just bought some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook for two coins. She is now ready to make another offer.


          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          ['[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.', '[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two coins is a fair price, I suppose.', '[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Two coins it is then.', '[14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville market and just bought some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook for two coins. She is now ready to make another offer.



    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
